P2para.Text: In Part 1 of that Schedule, after the entry for section 5(1A)(b), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g) there is inserted—

tr.td: Manufacturing or distributing, or possessing for distribution, prohibited weapons or ammunition

P1group.Title: Increased penalty for improper importation of firearms etc

P2para.Text: The Customs and Excise Management Act 1979 is amended as follows.

In section 50 (penalty for improper importation of goods), in subsection (5A) (firearms and counterfeit currency etc), for the words after “shall have effect” there is substituted “as if for the words “imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years” there were substituted the words “imprisonment for life””.
In that section—

P3para.Text: in subsection (4), after “(5A),” there is inserted “(5AA),”;
at the end of paragraph (a) of subsection (5A) there is inserted “or”;
paragraph (c) of that subsection and the word “or” before it are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In the case of an offence under subsection (2) or (3) above committed in connection with the prohibition contained in
section 20 of the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981, subsection (4)(b) above shall have effect as if for the words “7 years” there were substituted the words “10 years”.
In section 170 (penalty for fraudulent evasion of duty or prohibition, etc), in subsection (4A) (firearms and counterfeit currency etc)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a), for “subsection (2) or (3)” there is substituted “subsection (1) or (2)”;
for the words after “shall have effect” there is substituted “as if for the words “imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years” there were substituted the words “imprisonment for life””.

P2para.Text: In that section—

P3para.Text: in subsection (3), after “(4A),” there is inserted “(4AA),”;
at the end of paragraph (a) of subsection (4A) there is inserted “or”;
paragraph (c) of that subsection and the word “or” before it are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In the case of an offence under subsection (1) or (2) above committed in connection with the prohibitions contained in sections 20 and 21 of the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981, subsection (3)(b) above shall have effect as if for the words “7 years” there were substituted the words “10 years”.
In section 68 (offences in relation to exportation of prohibited or restricted goods), in subsection (4A) (firearms and counterfeit currency etc)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a) the words “or (3)” are omitted”;
for the words after “shall have effect” there is substituted “as if for the words “imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years” there were substituted the words “imprisonment for life””.

P2para.Text: In that section—

P3para.Text: in subsection (3), after “(4A)” there is inserted “, (4AA)”;
at the end of paragraph (a) of subsection (4A) there is inserted “or”;
paragraph (c) of that subsection and the word “or” before it are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In the case of an offence under subsection (2) above committed in connection with the prohibition contained in section 21 of the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981, subsection (3)(b) above shall have effect as if for the words “7 years” there were substituted the words “10 years”.

P1group.Title: British Transport Police: Crown status under Firearms Act 1968

P2para.Text: In section 54 of the Firearms Act 1968 (application to Crown servants), in subsection (3), at the end of paragraph (d) there is inserted “, or

P3para.Text: a member of the British Transport Police Force, or
a person employed by the British Transport Police Authority who is under the direction and control of the Chief Constable of the British Transport Police Force.

P2para.Text: The following are repealed—

P3para.Text: subsections (3A) and (3B) of section 54 of the Firearms Act 1968, and
paragraph 9 of Schedule 7 to the Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001 (which inserted those subsections).

P1group.Title: Offence of breaching forced marriage protection order

P2para.Text: The Family Law Act 1996 is amended as follows.
After section 63C there is inserted—
A person who without reasonable excuse does anything that the person is prohibited from doing by a forced marriage protection order is guilty of an offence.

In the case of a forced marriage protection order made by virtue of section 63D(1), a person can be guilty of an offence under this section only in respect of conduct engaged in at a time when the person was aware of the existence of the order.
Where a person is convicted of an offence under this section in respect of any conduct, that conduct is not punishable as a contempt of court.
A person cannot be convicted of an offence under this section in respect of any conduct which has been punished as a contempt of court.
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, or a fine, or both;
on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months, or a fine, or both.

P2para.Text: A reference in any enactment to proceedings under this Part, or to an order under this Part, does not include a reference to proceedings for an offence under this section or to an order made in proceedings for such an offence.
“Enactment” includes an enactment contained in subordinate legislation within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978.
For subsections (1) to (3) of section 63E there is substituted—
In any case where the court has power to make a forced marriage protection order, the court may accept an undertaking from the respondent instead of making the order.
But a court may not accept an undertaking under subsection (1) if it appears to the court—

P3para.Text: that the respondent has used or threatened violence against the person to be protected, and
that, for the person’s protection, it is necessary to make a forced marriage protection order so that any breach of it by the respondent may be punishable under section 63CA.

P2para.Text: In section 63J(2), for “the order” there is substituted “a forced marriage protection order”.
The following are repealed—

P3para.Text: section 63G(6) and (7);
section 63H;
section 63I;
section 63J(1);
in section 63K(1) the words “under section 63I(3) or”;
section 63L(4)(a).

P2para.Text: This section applies only in relation to conduct occurring on or after the day on which it comes into force.

In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, the reference to 12 months in section 63CA(5)(b) of the Family Law Act 1996 (inserted by subsection (2) above) is to be read as a reference to six months.
A person commits an offence if he or she—

P3para.Text: uses violence, threats or any other form of coercion for the purpose of causing another person to enter into a marriage, and
believes, or ought reasonably to believe, that the conduct may cause the other person to enter into the marriage without free and full consent.

P2para.Text: A person commits an offence if he or she—

P3para.Text: practices any form of deception with the intention of causing another person to leave the United Kingdom, and

intends the other person to be subjected to conduct outside the United Kingdom that is an offence under subsection (1) or would be an offence under that subsection if the victim were in England or Wales.

P2para.Text: “Marriage” means any religious or civil ceremony of marriage (whether or not legally binding).
It is irrelevant whether the conduct mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (1) is directed at the victim of the offence under that subsection or another person.
A person commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) only if, at the time of the coercion or deception—

P3para.Text: the person or the victim or both of them are in England or Wales,
neither the person nor the victim is in England or Wales but at least one of them is habitually resident in England and Wales, or
neither the person nor the victim is in the United Kingdom but at least one of them is a UK national.

P2para.Text: “UK national” means an individual who is—

P3para.Text: a British citizen, a British overseas territories citizen, a British National (Overseas) or a British Overseas citizen;
a person who under the British Nationality Act 1981 is a British subject; or
a British protected person within the meaning of that Act.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or to a fine or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years.

P2para.Text: In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, the reference to 12 months in subsection (7)(a) is to be read as a reference to six months.

P1group.Title: Regulations to be prepared or approved by the College

P2para.Text: In section 50 of the Police Act 1996 (regulations for police forces), after subsection (2) there is inserted—

If the College of Policing submits to the Secretary of State draft regulations with respect to any of the matters mentioned in subsection (1)(a), (b), (c) or (g), the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft unless the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: doing so would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to do so, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to do so.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations with respect to any of the matters mentioned in subsection (1)(a), (b), (c) or (g) unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.
In section 51 of that Act (regulations for special constables), after subsection (2) there is inserted—
If the College of Policing submits to the Secretary of State draft regulations with respect to—

P3para.Text: the ranks to be held by special constables,
the qualifications for appointment and promotion of special constables,
periods of service on probation, or
maintenance of personal records of special constables,

P2para.Text: the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft.
The duty in subsection (2ZA) does not apply if the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: making regulations in terms of the draft would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to make regulations in those terms, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to make regulations in those terms.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations with respect to the matters mentioned in subsection (2ZA) unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.
In section 53A of that Act (regulation of procedures and practices)—

P3para.Text: after subsection (1) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: If the College of Policing, having consulted the National Crime Agency, submits to the Secretary of State a draft of regulations under this section, the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft unless the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: doing so would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to do so, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to do so.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations under this section unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.

P3para.Text: subsections (2), (3), (4), (6) and (7) are repealed.

P2para.Text: In section 63 of that Act (Police Advisory Board for England and Wales, etc), in subsection (3)(a), before “with respect to” there is inserted “to which section 50(2ZB) applies or regulations”.
In section 97 of the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001 (regulations about police training etc)—

P3para.Text: after subsection (1) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: If the College of Policing submits to the Secretary of State a draft of regulations under this section, the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft unless the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: doing so would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to do so, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to do so.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations under this section unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.

P3para.Text: subsection (4) is repealed.

P1group.Title: Codes of practice issued by the College

P2para.Text: Section 39A of the Police Act 1996 (codes of practice for chief officers) is amended as follows.
For subsection (1) there is substituted—

The College of Policing may, with the approval of the Secretary of State, issue codes of practice relating to the discharge of their functions by chief officers of police if the College considers that—

P3para.Text: it is necessary to do so in order to promote the efficiency and effectiveness of police forces generally,
it is necessary to do so in order to facilitate the carrying out by members of any two or more police forces of joint or co-ordinated operations, or
it is for any other reason in the national interest to do so.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2), for “The Secretary of State may” there is substituted “The College of Policing may, with the approval of the Secretary of State,”.
For subsection (4) there is substituted—
The College of Policing shall consult with the National Crime Agency before issuing or revising a code of practice under this section.
In subsection (5), for “him” there is substituted “the College of Policing”.

P1group.Title: Guidance by the College about employment of civilian staff

P1para.Text: After section 53D of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Guidance about civilian staff employed by local policing bodies and chief officers

P2para.Text: In this section “relevant civilian staff” means individuals, other than constables, who—

P3para.Text: are employed by a local policing body or a chief officer of police, or

provide services to a local policing body or a chief officer of police, in pursuance of contractual arrangements but without being employed by the body or officer, and can be expected to have frequent contact with members of the public in the course of doing so.

P2para.Text: The College of Policing may issue guidance to local policing bodies and chief officers of police with regard to—

P3para.Text: the experience or qualifications to be expected of relevant civilian staff;
the training to be undertaken by such staff.

P2para.Text: The College may from time to time revise the whole or any part of any guidance issued under this section.
The College shall publish any guidance issued under this section and any revision of it.
In discharging any function to which guidance under this section relates, a local policing body or chief officer of police shall have regard to the guidance.

P1group.Title: Power to give directions to the College

P1para.Text: After section 40B of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Power to give directions to College of Policing

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may give a direction to the College of Policing requiring it to exercise any particular function that is conferred on the College by this Act or any other enactment.

The College of Policing shall carry out such other duties for the purpose of furthering the efficiency, effectiveness or integrity of the police as the Secretary of State may from time to time direct.

P1group.Title: Appointment of senior police officers as staff of the College

P1para.Text: After section 100 of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Appointment of senior police officers as staff of College of Policing

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person who—

P3para.Text: holds the office of constable with a rank above that of chief superintendent, or
hold that office and is eligible to be appointed to a rank above that of chief superintendent,

P2para.Text: is appointed as a member of the staff of the College of Policing.
The person continues to hold the office of constable while a member of the staff of the College.
On appointment—

P3para.Text: a person within subsection (1)(a) holds that office with same rank that the person held immediately before appointment, or with whatever higher rank the College decides;
a person within subsection (1)(b) holds that office with whatever rank, above that of chief superintendent, the College decides.

P1group.Title: Disclosure of information to the College

P1para.Text: After section 100A of the Police Act 1996 (inserted by section 109 above) there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Disclosure of information to College of Policing

P1para.Text: A person who, apart from this section, would not have power to disclose information to the College of Policing has power to do so where the disclosure is made for the purposes of the exercise by the College of any of its functions.
In Part 2 of the Police Reform Act 2002 (complaints and misconduct), before section 26C (inserted by section 11 of the Crime and Courts Act 2013) there is
inserted—

P2para.Text: The Commission and the College of Policing must enter into an agreement for the establishment, in relation to members of the College’s staff, of procedures corresponding or similar to those provided for by or under this Part.
An agreement under this section—

P3para.Text: must not be made or varied except with the approval of the Secretary of State; and
must not be terminated unless—

P4para.Text: it is replaced by another such agreement, and
the Secretary of State approves.

P2para.Text: An agreement under this section may contain provision for enabling the Commission to bring and conduct, or otherwise participate or intervene in, any proceedings that are identified by the agreement as disciplinary hearings in relation to members of the College’s staff.
Procedures established in accordance with an agreement under this section shall have no effect in relation to anything done outside England and Wales by any member of the College’s staff.

Pblock.Title: Review bodies for police remuneration etc

P1group.Title: Abolition of Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom

P2para.Text: The Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom is abolished.
Sections 61 and 62 of the Police Act 1996 (the Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom, and its functions with respect to regulations) are repealed.

P1group.Title: Establishment of Police Remuneration Review Body

P2para.Text: After Part 3 of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—
There shall be a body called the Police Remuneration Review Body.
It shall consist of—

P3para.Text: a chair appointed by the Prime Minister, and
five or more other members appointed by the Secretary of State, one of whom the Secretary of State may appoint as deputy chair.

P2para.Text: Before making an appointment, the Prime Minister or the Secretary of State shall consult the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland.
The Secretary of State may by order—

P3para.Text: change the name of the body established by this section, and
make consequential amendments to any provision contained in or made under this or any other Act.

P2para.Text: A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (4) shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
Schedule 4B shall have effect in relation to the Police Remuneration Review Body.

P1group.Title: Reports by the Police Remuneration Review Body

P2para.Text: The Police Remuneration Review Body shall consider and report on any matter referred to it by the Secretary of State that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of police clothing, personal equipment and accoutrements,

P2para.Text: as regards members of police forces of or below the rank of chief superintendent or police cadets appointed under section 28.
A report under subsection (1) shall be submitted to—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State, and
the Prime Minister,

P2para.Text: and the Secretary of State shall arrange for it to be published.
The Police Remuneration Review Body shall also consider and report on any matter referred to it by the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of equipment,

P2para.Text: as regards members of the Police Service of Northern Ireland of or below the rank of chief superintendent, police trainees appointed under section 39 of the Police (Northern Ireland) Act 2000 or police cadets appointed under section 42 of that Act.
A report under subsection (3) shall be submitted to the Department of Justice, and that Department shall arrange for it to be published.
When referring a matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body, the Secretary of State or Department of Justice may give directions to that body about—

P3para.Text: the time within which it must report;
considerations to which it must have particular regard;
the evidence that it must obtain;
matters on which it is to make recommendations.

P2para.Text: The Police Remuneration Review Body may include in a report under this section any recommendations it considers appropriate arising out of matters referred to it under this section (whether or not it is required to do so by a direction under subsection (5)).
A reference or direction under this section may be varied or revoked.
After Schedule 4A to that Act there is inserted the Schedule set out in Schedule 5 to this Act.
An order under section 141(6) may include provision requiring the first members of the Police Remuneration Review Body to be, or to include, persons of a particular description.

P1group.Title: Consultation about regulations: England and Wales

P2para.Text: After section 52 of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Regulations about hours, leave or pay: consultation etc

P2para.Text: This section applies where the Secretary of State is proposing to make regulations under section 50 or 52 on a matter that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of police clothing, personal equipment and accoutrements.

P2para.Text: In the case of regulations under section 50 concerning members of police forces of or below the rank of chief superintendent, or regulations under section 52, before making the regulations the Secretary of State shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(1), and
consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: In the case of regulations under section 50 concerning members of police forces above the rank of chief superintendent, before making the regulations the Secretary of State shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: consider advice on the matter from the Senior Salaries Review Body, or
where subsection (4) applies, refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(1) and consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies where—

P3para.Text: the regulations would affect members of police forces who are not above the rank of chief superintendent as well as those who are, and
the Secretary of State thinks that it would be preferable for the matter to be considered by the same body.

P2para.Text: The duty to consider advice from the Senior Salaries Review Body or to refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body does not apply if the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: there is not enough time to do so because the need to make the regulations is so urgent, or
it is unnecessary to do so by reason of the nature of the proposed regulations.

P2para.Text: In all cases, before making the regulations the Secretary of State shall supply a draft of them to, and consider any representations made by, persons whom the Secretary of State considers to represent the interests of—

P3para.Text: the persons and bodies who between them maintain police forces;
chief officers of police;
members of police forces;
police cadets appointed under section 28.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order amend this section in consequence of a change in the name or functions of the body for the time being specified in subsection (3)(a).
A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (7) shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

In section 63 of that Act (Police Advisory Board for England and Wales, etc), in subsection (3)(a), for “regulations with respect to any of the matters mentioned in section 61(1)” there is substituted “regulations of a kind referred to in section 52A(1)”.
In section 1 of the Police Pensions Act 1976 (police pensions regulations)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), for “the Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom” there is substituted “the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales”;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: When carrying out consultation under subsection (1) above the Secretary of State shall also invite the views of the Northern Ireland Policing Board and the Police Association for Northern Ireland.
In section 52 of the Police Act 1996 (regulations for police cadets), at the end there is inserted—

Before making regulations under this section relating to pensions the Secretary of State shall consult with the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales and shall also invite the views of the Northern Ireland Policing Board and the Police Association for Northern Ireland.

In Schedule 3 to the Police and Justice Act 2006 (power to merge police pension schemes), in paragraph 3(3), for “the Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom” there is substituted “the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales and shall also invite the views of the Northern Ireland Policing Board and the Police Association for Northern Ireland”.
In section 25 of the Police (Northern Ireland) Act 1998 (regulations for the Police Service of Northern Ireland)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (8), the words “, other than regulations made by virtue of subsection (2)(j), (k) or (l)” are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: Subsection (8) does not apply to—

P3para.Text: regulations made by virtue of subsection (2)(k), as to which the Department of Justice shall invite the views of the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales, or
regulations made by virtue of subsection (2)(j) or (l), as to which section 25A applies.

P2para.Text: After that section there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Regulations about hours, leave, pay or equipment: consultation etc

P2para.Text: This section applies where the Department of Justice is proposing to make regulations under section 25 by virtue of subsection (2)(j) or (l) of that section.
In the case of regulations concerning officers of or below the rank of chief superintendent, before making the regulations the Department of Justice shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(3) of the Police Act 1996, and
consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: In the case of regulations concerning officers above the rank of chief superintendent, before making the regulations the Department of Justice shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: consider advice on the matter from the Senior Salaries Review Body, or
where subsection (4) applies, refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(3) of the Police Act 1996 and consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies where—

P3para.Text: the regulations would affect officers who are not above the rank of chief superintendent as well as those who are, and
the Department of Justice thinks that it would be preferable for the matter to be considered by the same body.

P2para.Text: The duty to consider advice from the Senior Salaries Review Body or to refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body does not apply if Department of Justice considers that—

P3para.Text: there is not enough time to do so because the need to make the regulations is so urgent, or
it is unnecessary to do so by reason of the nature of the proposed regulations.

P2para.Text: In all cases, before making the regulations the Department of Justice shall supply a draft of them to, and consider any representations made by—

P3para.Text: the Board,
the Police Association, and
the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: The Department of Justice may by order amend this section in consequence of a change in the name or functions of the body for the time being specified in subsection (3)(a).
In section 41 of the Police (Northern Ireland) Act 2000 (police trainees and police reserve trainees)—

P3para.Text: at the end of subsection (6) there is inserted “, other than regulations to which subsection (8) applies”;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: Subsection (8) applies to regulations under subsection (3), concerning police trainees, on a matter that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of equipment.

P2para.Text: Before making any such regulations the Department of Justice shall—

P3para.Text: (subject to subsection (9)) refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(3) of the Police Act 1996 and consider that body’s report on the matter, and
supply a draft of the regulations to, and consider any representations made by—

P4para.Text: the Board,
the Police Association, and
the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: The duty in subsection (8)(a) does not apply if the Department of Justice considers that—

P3para.Text: there is not enough time to refer to the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body because the need to make the regulations is so urgent, or
it is unnecessary to do so by reason of the nature of the proposed regulations.

P1group.Title: Application of IPCC provisions to contractors

P1para.Text: In section 12 of the Police Reform Act 2002 (complaints, matters and persons to which Part 2 applies), at the end there is inserted—

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may make regulations providing that, for the purposes of this Part—

P3para.Text: a contractor,
a sub-contractor of a contractor, or
an employee of a contractor or a sub-contractor,

P2para.Text: is to be treated as a person serving with the police.
Regulations under subsection (8) may make modifications to this Part in its application to those persons.
In subsection (8) “contractor” means a person who has entered into a contract with a local policing body or a chief officer to provide services to a chief officer.

P1group.Title: Application to IPCC of provisions about investigation of offences

P2para.Text: In Schedule 3 to the Police Reform Act 2002 (handling of complaints and conduct matters etc), paragraph 19 (investigations by the Independent Police Complaints Commission itself) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (6), for the words from “provide that such provisions” to “shall apply” there is substituted “provide that—

P3para.Text: such provisions of the 1984 Act relating to investigations of offences conducted by police officers as may be specified in the order, and
such provisions of a code of practice under section 60, 60A or 66 of that Act as may be so specified,

P2para.Text: shall apply
After sub-paragraph (6) there is inserted—

An order under sub-paragraph (6) may, in particular, provide that where a provision applied by the order allows a power to be exercised only if an authorisation is given by a police officer of or above a particular rank, the authorisation may be given by a member of the Commission’s staff of or above a specified grade.

P1para.Text: After paragraph 19 of Schedule 3 to the Police Reform Act 2002 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Investigations by the Commission: power to serve information notice

P2para.Text: The Commission may serve upon any person an information notice requiring the person to provide it with information that it reasonably requires for the purposes of an investigation in accordance with paragraph 19.
But an information notice must not require a person—

P3para.Text: to provide information that might incriminate the person;
to provide an item subject to legal privilege within the meaning of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (see section 10 of that Act);
to provide communications data within the meaning of Chapter 2 of Part 1 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000;
to make a disclosure that would be prohibited by Part 1 of that Act.

P2para.Text: An information notice must—

P3para.Text: specify or describe the information that is required by the Commission and the form in which it must be provided;
specify the period within which the information must be provided;
give details of the right of appeal against the information notice under paragraph 19ZC.

P2para.Text: The period specified under sub-paragraph (3)(b) must not end before the end of the period within which an appeal can be brought against the notice and, if such an appeal is brought, the information need not be provided pending the determination or withdrawal of the appeal.
The Commission may cancel an information notice by written notice to the person on whom it was served.

P1group.Title: Failure to comply with information notice

P2para.Text: If a person who has received an information notice—

P3para.Text: fails or refuses to provide the information required by the notice, or
knowingly or recklessly provides information in response to the notice that is false in a material respect,

P2para.Text: the Commission may certify in writing to the High Court that the person has failed to comply with the information notice.

The High Court may then inquire into the matter and, after hearing any witness who may be produced against or on behalf of the person, and after hearing any statement offered in defence, deal with the person as if the person had committed a contempt of court.
A person on whom an information notice is served may appeal against the notice to the First-tier Tribunal on the ground that the notice is not in accordance with the law.
If the Tribunal considers that the notice is not in accordance with the law—

P3para.Text: it must quash the notice, and
it may give directions to the Commission in relation to the service of a further information notice.

P1group.Title: Intelligence and intercept information: restriction on further disclosure

P2para.Text: The Commission must not disclose (whether under section 20 or 21 or otherwise)—

P3para.Text: intelligence service information that it receives under an information notice,
intercept information that it receives under an information notice, or
the fact that it has received such intelligence service information or intercept information,

P2para.Text: unless the relevant authority consents to the disclosure.
If the Commission discloses to another person—

P3para.Text: intelligence service information that it receives under an information notice,
intercept information that it receives under an information notice, or
the fact that it has received such intelligence service information or intercept information,

P2para.Text: that person must not disclose that information or that fact unless the relevant authority consents to the disclosure.
In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “intelligence service information” means information which was obtained (directly or indirectly) from an intelligence service or which relates to an intelligence service;
“intelligence service” means—
the Security Service,
the Secret Intelligence Service,
the Government Communications Headquarters (“GCHQ”), or
any part of Her Majesty’s forces (within the meaning of the Armed Forces Act 2006), or of the Ministry of Defence, which engages in intelligence activities;
“intercept information” means information relating to any of the matters mentioned in section 19(3) of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000;
“relevant authority” means—
in the case of intelligence service information obtained from the Security Service, the Director-General of the Security Service;
in the case of intelligence service information obtained from the Secret Intelligence Service, the Chief of the Secret Intelligence Service;
in the case of intelligence service information received from GCHQ, the Director of GCHQ;
in the case of intelligence service information obtained from Her Majesty’s forces or the Ministry of Defence, the Secretary of State;
in the case of intercept information, the person to whom the relevant interception warrant is or was addressed;
“relevant interception warrant” means the interception warrant issued under section 5 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 that relates to the intercept information.

why the person has not taken, or does not propose to take, any action in response.

P2para.Text: The person must provide the response to the Commission before the end of the period of 56 days beginning with the day on which the recommendation was made, unless sub-paragraph (3) applies.

The Commission may extend the period of 56 days following an application received before the end of the period; and if the Commission grants an extension, the person must provide the response before the end of the extended period.

But if proceedings for judicial review of the Commission’s decision to make a recommendation are started during the period allowed by sub-paragraph (2) or (3), that period is extended by however many days the proceedings are in progress.
On receiving a response, the Commission must, within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the Commission received it—

P3para.Text: publish the response, and
send a copy of it to any person who was sent a copy of the recommendation under paragraph 28A(6)(b),

The person giving the response may, at the time of providing it to the Commission, make representations to the Commission asserting that the requirements of publication and disclosure under sub-paragraph (5) should not apply to the response, or to particular parts of it.

P3para.Text: that the response should not be published, or that only parts of it should be published;
that the response should not be disclosed, or that only parts of the response should be disclosed.

P2para.Text: Where, following a decision on representations, the Commission decides to publish or disclose a response (in whole or in part), it must do so only after the person giving the response has been informed of the Commission’s decision, and—

P3para.Text: in a case where the Commission has decided to accept all of the representations, it must do so within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which it received the response;

P2para.Text: But if proceedings for judicial review of the Commission’s decision to reject a representation are started during the period of 7 days referred to in sub-paragraph (8)(b)(ii)—

P3para.Text: the Commission must not publish or disclose the response while the proceedings are in progress;

P2para.Text: Where a local policing body or a chief officer makes a response under this paragraph, the body or officer must, at the time the Commission publishes the response, also publish the response (to the same extent as published by the Commission) and the recommendation under paragraph 28A.

Pblock.Title: Non-UK extradition: transit through the United Kingdom

P1group.Title: Facilitating transit through the United Kingdom

P2para.Text: The relevant UK authority may issue a transit certificate in relation to the non-UK extradition of a person if that authority has been requested
to facilitate the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition.
If the relevant UK authority issues a transit certificate in relation to the non-UK extradition of a person, an authorised officer may do any or all of the following—

P3para.Text: escort the person from, or to, any means of transport used for the purposes of the extradition;
take the person into custody to facilitate the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition;
search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to cause physical injury to that person or any other person;

in a case where the person has been taken into custody under paragraph (b), search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to escape from custody.

P2para.Text: An authorised officer searching a person in the exercise of a power conferred by subsection (2)(c) or (d) may seize any item found if the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that the person searched might use the item—

P3para.Text: to cause physical injury to that person or any other person; or
in a case where the person has been taken into custody, to escape from custody.

P2para.Text: If no request is made under subsection (1) in relation to the non-UK extradition of a person, or if such a request is made but a transit certificate is not issued, that does not—

P3para.Text: prevent the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition; or
affect the powers which an authorised officer has (otherwise than under this section) in relation to the person while in the United Kingdom.

P1group.Title: Unscheduled arrival in the United Kingdom

P2para.Text: This section applies in a case where—

P3para.Text: a person is being extradited,
the extradition is a non-UK extradition, and
the person makes an unscheduled arrival in the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: An authorised officer may do any or all of the following—

P3para.Text: take the person into custody to facilitate the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition;
search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to cause physical injury to that person or any other person;

in a case where the person has been taken into custody under paragraph (a), search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to escape from custody.

P2para.Text: Any power conferred by subsection (2) may be exercised—

P3para.Text: upon the unscheduled arrival, or
at any later time when the person is still in the United Kingdom after the unscheduled arrival.

P2para.Text: A person taken into custody under this section may be kept in custody until the expiry of the period of 72 hours beginning with the time when the person is taken (or first taken) into custody under this section.

But if a transit certificate is issued under section 189A in respect of the non-UK extradition of the person, the person must not be kept in custody under this section after the issue of the certificate.
Subsection (5) does not prevent the person from being taken into custody under section 189A.

An authorised officer searching a person in the exercise of a power conferred by subsection (2)(b) or (c) may seize any item found if the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that the person searched might use the item—

P3para.Text: to cause physical injury to that person or any other person; or
in a case where the person has been taken into custody, to escape from custody.

P1group.Title: Exercise of the extradition transit powers

P2para.Text: The extradition transit powers include power to use reasonable force when necessary.
An authorised officer may not, when exercising a relevant search power, require a person to remove any clothing other than an outer coat, jacket, headgear or gloves.
Any item seized from a person in the exercise of a relevant search power may be retained while the person is in transit through the United Kingdom.
The Secretary of State must issue a code of practice in connection with—

P3para.Text: the exercise of extradition transit powers;
the retention, use and return of anything seized under a relevant search power.

P2para.Text: If the Secretary of State proposes to issue a code of practice under this section the Secretary of State must—

P3para.Text: publish a draft of the code;
consider any representations made to the Secretary of State about the draft;
if the Secretary of State thinks it appropriate, modify the draft in the light of any such representations.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State must lay the code before Parliament.
After doing so the Secretary of State may bring the code into operation by order.

The Secretary of State may revise the whole or any part of a code issued under this section and issue the code as revised; and subsections (2) to (4) apply to such a revised code as they apply to the original code.
A failure by an authorised officer to comply with a provision of a code issued under this section does not of itself make the authorised officer liable to criminal or civil proceedings.
A code issued under this section is admissible in evidence in any proceedings and must be taken into account by a court in determining any question to which it appears to the court to be relevant.
If the Secretary of State publishes a draft code of practice in connection with a matter specified in subsection (1) before the date on which this section comes into force—

P3para.Text: the draft is as effective as one published under subsection (2) on or after that date;
representations made to the Secretary of State about the draft before that date are as effective as such representations made after that date;
modifications made by the Secretary of State to the draft in the light of any such representations before that date are as effective as any such modifications made on or after that date.

P2para.Text: An “authorised officer” is—

P3para.Text: a constable, or
a person who is of a description specified by the Secretary of State by order.

P2para.Text: A National Crime Agency officer, prison officer, or any other person who has the powers of a constable (but is not a constable)—

P3para.Text: does not have the extradition transit powers by virtue of having the powers of a constable; and
accordingly, has the extradition transit powers only if the person is of a description specified under subsection (1)(b).

P2para.Text: These expressions have the meanings given—

Para.Text: “extradition transit powers” means the powers under—
section 189A (except the power to issue transit certificates), and
section 189B;
“foreign territory” means a territory outside the United Kingdom;
“non-UK extradition” means extradition from one foreign territory to another foreign territory;
“relevant search power” means a power of search under—
section 189A(2)(c) or (d), or
section 189B(2)(b) or (c);
“relevant UK authority” means—
the National Crime Agency (in the case of a non-UK extradition to a category 1 territory), or
the Secretary of State (in any other case).

P2para.Text: A reference to the transit of a person through the United Kingdom is a reference to the person arriving in, being in, and departing from the United Kingdom (whether or not the person travels within the United Kingdom between arrival and departure).
This section applies for the purposes of section 189A to 189D (and this section).

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order—

P1group.Title: Low-value shoplifting to be a summary offence

P2para.Text: Low-value shoplifting is triable only summarily.

But where a person accused of low-value shoplifting is aged 18 or over, and appears or is brought before the court before the summary trial of the offence begins, the court must give the person the opportunity of electing to be tried by the Crown Court for the offence and, if the person elects to be so tried—

P3para.Text: subsection (1) does not apply, and
the court must send the person to the Crown Court for trial for the offence.

P2para.Text: “Low-value shoplifting” means an offence under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 in circumstances where—

P3para.Text: the value of the stolen goods does not exceed £200,
the goods were being offered for sale in a shop or any other premises, stall, vehicle or place from which there is carried on a trade or business, and
at the time of the offence, the person accused of low-value shoplifting was, or was purporting to be, a customer or potential customer of the person offering the goods for sale.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (3)(a)—

P3para.Text: the value of the stolen goods is the price at which they were being offered for sale at the time of the offence, and

where the accused is charged on the same occasion with two or more offences of low-value shoplifting, the reference to the value involved has effect as if it were a reference to the aggregate of the values involved.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of low-value shoplifting is liable on summary conviction to—

P3para.Text: imprisonment for a period not exceeding 51 weeks (or 6 months, if the offence was committed before the commencement of section 281(4) and (5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003),
a fine, or
both.

P2para.Text: A person convicted of low-value shoplifting by a magistrates’ court may not appeal to the Crown Court against the conviction on the ground that the convicting court was mistaken as to whether the offence was one of low-value shoplifting.
For the purposes of this section, any reference to low-value shoplifting includes aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of low-value shoplifting.
